journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Nanoscale elastoplastic adhesion of wet asperities

article-meta.aff: 1Wolfson School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Loughborough University, Loughborough, UK
2Baskin School of Engineering, University of California Santa Cruz, CA, USA

fn.p: Currently at: University of Southampton Malaysia Campus (USMC), Nusajaya, Johor, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: WWF Chong, Wolfson School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Loughborough University, Loughborough, LE11 3TU, UK. Email: w.w.f.chong@lboro.ac.uk

abstract.p: Accurate prediction of friction is crucial for design and efficient operation of many devices, comprising various contacts. In practice, contacting surfaces are rough and often wet. There are several mechanisms, which contribute to friction, including viscous shear of a coherent fluid film, as well as that of a thin adsorbed layer of boundary active molecular species. Additionally, adhesion and elastoplastic deformation of asperities on counterface surfaces may occur. Traditional friction models are based on statistical representation of surface topography as well as description of boundary shear films based on the theoretical lubricant film Eyring shear stress. The study reports a more realistic friction model than the traditional ones, which do not take into account the wet nature of the asperities. The fluid–surface interaction is a main contribution of the article, not hitherto reported in literature. It is shown that ignoring the effect of surface wetness can lead to the over-estimation of boundary friction and under-estimation of contact load-carrying capacity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Like most natural phenomena, surface interactions are governed by various competing kinetics operating at different length scales. Contact characteristics in the microscale lubricated conjunctions are now reasonably well understood, depending on the classification of various regimes of lubrication.1 This classification is affected by contact geometry, surface topography, mechanical properties of the conjunctional bounding solid surfaces, bulk rheological properties of any intervening fluid, and loading and kinematics of the contact. Viscous behaviour of a fluid film accounts for both the load-carrying capacity of such conjunctions, as well as the generated friction. As the film thickness is further reduced, boundary interactions occur and a proportion of contact load and friction are carried and contributed by the interactions of the ubiquitous asperities on the real rough surfaces.1 Asperity load and friction are complex phenomena as they require good representation of surface topography to account for the adhesion of asperity pairs as well as their elastoplastic ploughing in any oblique contact.1–4 These traditional approaches use statistical representation of topography, which for engineering surfaces are multi-scale and fairly random.5 Nayak6 showed that Gaussian asperity distribution used in rough surface contact models such as that of Greenwood and Williamson model3 is not applicable to all rough surface contacts. This was also noted by Sayles and Thomas,7 who showed that surface topography had a multi-scale nature. Therefore, the need for scale-independent contact models has become apparent, leading to the development of fractal analysis.

A fractal geometry refers to a fragmented topology, which can be divided into its constituents, each of which contains some of the overall geometry.8 Majumdar and Bhushan9 applied the Weierstrass and Mandelbrot8 (WM) fractal function to develop a fractal contact model. Yan and Komvopoulos10 also proposed an algorithm based on the WM fractal function to generate a three-dimensional fractal surface. The model was developed to investigate the elastic-fully plastic dry contact of rough surfaces. Bora et al.,11 Morrow and Lovell,12 and Morag and Etsion13 extended the work of Yan and Komvopoulos10 to include other kinetic laws governing friction (e.g. surface adhesion). Most fractal-based rough surface analyses consider asperity contact deformation, based on the classical Hertzian theory with few attempts made to include either elastoplastic deformation13 and/or boundary adhesion11 of asperities. Boundary adhesion models for elastic asperity contacts (e.g. JKR,14 DMT15 and Maugis–Dugdale model16) are fairly well understood. When an asperity is further loaded, its deformation may eventually exceed the yield point of the material, leading to plastic deformation. This is commonly solved by assuming an elastic-fully plastic asperity contact.10,11,17 The fully plastic region has been studied by Pollock,18 Pethica and Tabor19 and Maugis and Pollock.20 However, as the asperity deformation exceeds the elastic limit some work hardening occurs in case of ductile materials.1

There has been a dearth of analyses with regard to the transition state of an asperity pair contact from elastic to elastoplastic and finally onto fully plastic state. Kogut and Etsion21 proposed an elastoplastic asperity model for a Hertzian type contact, based on finite element analysis. They later extended their model to include the effect of boundary adhesion.22 The DMT contact model, including adhesion15 was used, which assumed that the attractive forces act immediately outside the Hertzian contact area. This limits the use of the model to features with sufficiently small radii of curvature, such as those typically at asperity summits of stiff materials which, for example, would come into contact with an AFM tip. The basis of this assumption is that the adhesion force might only be significant with respect to the contact load in the elastic regime and in the early stages of elastoplastic behaviour. The adhesion force may then become negligible when the contact becomes fully plastic. Jackson and Green23 derived a set of expressions to describe the elastoplastic behaviour of a sphere contacting a rigid semi-infinite flat plane. The model can be used at macro-scale (e.g. bearings) or at microscale (e.g. asperity) contacts. The proposed set of expressions was extended for use with rough surface analysis.24 The von Mises criterion can then be used to describe the yielding of the material. Jackson and Green's model considers the geometry and mechanical properties which is not included in the work of Kogut and Etsion.21 It also points out that the material hardness changes with the evolving contact geometry and materials' mechanical properties. Jackson and Green23 define hardness as a measure of material resistance to dislocation which is related to its yield strength. Their model is set up in a manner which embeds plastic deformation of an asperity in the expressions derived.

There is rarely any purely dry contact of surfaces. A layer of fluid is formed on all contacting solid surfaces, either intentionally through lubrication or unintentionally through condensation (e.g. a mono-layer of water molecules is formed in few tens of microsecond in normal atmosphere25). Therefore, as the separation between a pair of molecularly smooth (fractal rough) surfaces gradually diminishes prior to any direct contact, various kinetic laws should be considered. Komvopoulos26 used the fractal geometry to analyse the contact between rough surfaces in the presence of van der Waals interactions, as well as meniscus, electrostatic and deformation forces. Impact dynamics including asperity adhesion, elastic deformation and micro-meniscus formation were also investigated for rough surfaces, including for fairly smooth micro-electromechanical gears by Teodorescu et al.,27,28 which included the effect of hydrophobic self-assembled mono-layers with asymptotic accumulation of water condensation layers under normal atmospheric conditions. Micro-menisci are then formed between the summits of opposing asperities. It has been shown that prior to the formation of such menisci, the density distribution of fluid molecules near the smooth solid surfaces differs from that in the bulk of any ultra-thin film formed between them.29 This phenomenon gives rise to an attractive-repulsive kinetic interaction known as solvation.1 In fact, in diminishing gaps of the order of several molecular diameters deep of an intervening fluid, this effect is dominant, if no meniscus bridges are formed as shown experimentally by Chan and Horn30 and Horn and Israelachvilli,31 and by Matsuoka and Kato,32 and Al-Samieh and Rahnejat33–35 through numerical analyses using an empirical relationship for the generated solvation pressure, proposed in Horn and Israelachvilli.31 It is, therefore, clear that any conjunction should be viewed as a lubricant-surface system as shown by Erdemir.36

At the level of asperity summits, the shear characteristics of a molecular length film was studied by Chong et al.37 using the same empirical approach as in Matsuoka and Kato,32 Al-Samieh and Rahnejat33–35 for an idealised fluid of mono-molecular species, confined between atomically smooth contiguous surfaces. They predicted the shearing of the diminutive film using the modified Eyring thermal activation cage model, proposed by Briscoe and Evans,38 for which the solvation pressure was assumed to represent the activation potential barrier. However, the empirical representation of solvation limits this approach to idealised fluids with mono-molecular species such as octamethylcyclotetrasiloxane (OMCTS). Furthermore, real fluids contain boundary active molecular species with varying adsorption potential to stick to the solid barriers. This would affect the solvation potential near the surfaces. Using a statistical mechanics approach, based on Ornstein and Zernike integral equation,39 Chong et al.40 extended their previous work to include a bi-molecular fluid system, representing a base lubricant with a boundary active species. A further extension of this approach included long linear boundary-active chain molecules with an imposed connectivity constraint.41 They found out that an optimum molecular packing order and mixture exists for any coherent adsorbed film formed at the solid barriers, which is in accord with the findings of Wu and Dacre42 and Tung and Gao.43,44 These reported analyses were applicable to atomically smooth surfaces and should be extended to rough surfaces with asperity adhesion, ploughing and elastoplastic deformation. This article deals with the integration of wet asperity deformation and adhesion, with an intervening bulk thin fluid film and a surface adsorbed molecular layer. Such an approach has not hitherto been reported in literature.

sec.title: Mathematical Model
sec.p: Friction of interacting rough surfaces is a multi-scale phenomenon. Therefore, the understanding of various kinetic mechanisms underlying friction at asperity level is important. In the current study, asperity interactions are described in terms of the fractal representation of a rough surface. This area is representative of a larger rough measured surface, assumed to follow certain statistical characteristics and reconstructed through use of a random number generator and subsequent use of fractal analysis (section ‘Computation procedure’). The aim is to develop a boundary friction model, including adhesion of wet asperities. The total friction may be predicted as (1)Ff=Fb+Fv where Fb is the boundary friction component and Fv = ηAueαp/h is the viscous shear component of any uninterrupted bulk lubricant film of thickness h, formed between two rough contiguous surfaces, u is the relative sliding velocity of the surfaces, p is the total contact pressure and α is the lubricant viscosity coefficient. The term η refers to the bulk dynamic viscosity of the lubricant. The boundary component, Fb comprises two distinct contributions: shear of an ultra-thin surface adsorbed molecular layer and dry boundary adhesion of asperity pairs. Thus (2)Fb=Fs+Fadh where the term Fs refers to the friction as a result of the shear of a thin adsorbed film at the summit of rough surface asperities, which are considered as smooth and of significantly larger dimension than the molecular size of any boundary active species within the fluid composition. In a nanoscale conjunction with gaps of the order of several molecular diameters of the average species in the fluid, oscillatory density variations occur near the solid barriers (summits of asperities).29,37 Therefore, as a first approximation, the solvation component of shear is assumed to exist in gaps of less than 10 nm in the first instance. Solvation occurs because of the constraining effect of the asperity summit pairs. Finally, dry direct contact of asperity pairs under load causes them to form cold welded junctions. Fadh is the resisting force required to break these adhesive junctions.

sec.title: Fractal surface characterisation
sec.p: The parameters D and G can be obtained experimentally by plotting the power spectrum of the fractal surface against the frequency of the AFM measurement on a logarithmic scale. The parameter D also refers to the slope of the power spectrum–frequency curve, while G is the intersection of the power spectrum of the fractal surface at the null frequency.

sec.title: Dry contact
sec.p:
Based on the fractal geometry, Yan and Komvopoulos10 derived the asperity interference, δ and the equivalent curvature radius of an asperity tip, R as (4)δ=L (GL )(D-2) (lnγM )1/2∑m=1 Mγno(D-3)
(5)R=(a')22δ where a′ is the truncated contact radius (Figure 1) and no = ln(L/2a′)/lnγ is the frequency index. Figure 1.
Single asperity contact – Maugis–Dugdale model.

With a known asperity curvature radius and interference, Maugis adhesion model using the Dugdale potential16 to describe the attractive forces between contacting surfaces, are integrated with the fractal analysis of a rough surface. The actual contact radii: a and c (Figure 1) can now be computed by simultaneous solution for the contact load, P and deflection, δ of an assumed elastic hemispherical asperity as (6)P=4E*a33R-2σ0 [c2cos-1 (ac )+ac2-a2 ]
(7)δ=a2R- (2σ0E* )c2-a2 where σ0 is the adhesive force intensity which extends to the contact radius c and E*= ((1-ν1 2)/E1+(1-ν2 2)/E2 )-1. The adhesive traction for the Dugdale model diminishes at the conjunctional separations exceeding Δγ/σ0. Therefore (8)h(c)+ha(c)=Δγσ0 where h(c)=c22R-a2R+1πR [ (2a2-c2 )sin-1 (ac )+ac2-a2 ]ha(c)=4σ0πE* [c2-a2cos-1 (ac )+a-c ]

As an asperity pair is further loaded, they may plastically deform. The principle used by Kogut and Etsion22 and Peng and Guo17 is to integrate adhesion with an elastoplastic model. This is the approach adopted here. Therefore, to integrate the elastoplastic model proposed by Jackson and Green23 with the Maugis–Dugdale adhesion model,16 it is assumed that the elastoplastic deformation occurs strictly within the contact area, whilst asperity adhesion takes place outside the contact area in a circular rim. This reduces the model to the DMT assumption.15 As a result, the normalised contact load, P¯ and the normalised asperity deflection, δ¯ for an elastoplastic contact, using the modified Maugis–Dugdale model becomes (9)P¯=P¯1-λa¯2 [m2-1+m2cos-1 (1m )-m+1 ]
(10)δ¯=δ¯1-4 3a¯m2-1 where the components, P¯1 and δ¯1 are given in Appendix 2. Hence, the friction caused by adhesion of a pair of asperities, dFadh may be obtained as (11)dFadh=τaA where τa is the interfacial shear strength and A (= πc2) is the actual asperity summit contact area. The friction force obtained is necessary to overcome the work of adhesion. When the asperities on the surfaces interact and undergo elastoplastic deformation, where the plastically deformed region of contact is regarded as an interlock (Figure 2). During the elastoplastic deformation, the contact undergoes a combination of adhesive and ploughing contributions to friction. Figure 2.
Asperity during ploughing: cross section perpendicular on the direction of motion.

Any relative motion of the surfaces in the interlocked region (plastically deformed region) would be through local displacement of an opposing asperity.1 The local displacement of an asperity may occur through ploughing of the softer one of an opposing asperity pair (Figure 2). Therefore, to consider the effect of ploughing friction, the friction force for a single asperity contact as a result of adhesion is modified as (12)dFadh=2 3Hhpdp+τa. [πc2-πdp 2 ] where the separation hp = δ − δc is indicated by δ > δc, dp=8hpR and hp is the penetration depth.

sec.title: Boundary lubrication
sec.p: Contacting surfaces are rarely dry. They are often covered by a boundary layer as in normal atmosphere, where a mono-layer of water molecules adsorbs to all surfaces in few tens of microsecond. Lubricants are often furnished with boundary active species to form a low shear strength layer or protect the contiguous surfaces against oxidation or merely to remove debris or oxidation products (such as surfactants). Therefore, as an initial investigation an idealised fluid, comprising two molecular species is assumed. One is regarded as a hard spherical molecule with no adsorption potential, as an allusion to any base lubricant molecular species. The other is a small percentage of a long chain molecule, used as an additive, particularly as a friction modifier for boundary lubrication. The long chain molecule is regarded as boundary active with an appropriate adsorption potential.

A basic model described by Chong et al.41 is shown in Figure 3, where both types of molecule are shown. They interact with each other, as well as with the atoms of the bounding surfaces. The interaction of hard molecules, confined by planar walls, can be modelled using the hard sphere model of Perram and Smith45 (Figure 3). For long chain molecules, the concept of ‘sticky’ hard spheres proposed by Baxter46 is used, where adsorption (as the underlying mechanism for stickiness) is assumed to occur at one end of the molecular chain. Furthermore, for molecular chains a connectivity constraint is imposed.47,48 Figure 3.
Fluid mixtures of spheres/chains of m-mer with one end of the chain (represented by particle 1) adsorbing to the surface.

The solvation pressure between any pair of approaching molecularly smooth surfaces arises as a result of the fluid particles being constrained in a diminishing gap of the same scale as their molecular size. Using the Derjaguin approximation29,49 for hard spheres confined by macroscopic flat bodies, the solvation pressure, ps becomes (13)ps=-d2dr*21 2πReff[kBT(g*(r*)-1)] where Reff = σασβ/2(σα + σβ) is the effective diameter, kB is the Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature of the fluid system, α and β refer to the hard spherical species and g*(r*) is the pair correlation function at distance r*.

Friction generated by the ultra-thin adsorbed films on nominally molecularly smooth surfaces follow a non-Newtonian shear due to chemical reactions which are based on the thermal activation energy. Eyring50 developed a model, which described the viscosity of fluids under such conditions. It assumes that the motion of a volume of fluid molecules takes place in the presence of a ‘cage-like’ potential barrier by their mere closely packed arrangement in the bulk. In order to overcome this potential and escape the cage, the fluid molecules strive to surmount the activation barrier potential. This is the thermal activation model which Eyring50 modified to include the effect of prevailing pressure. At the assumed smooth summit of asperities considered to be significantly larger than the effective diameter of molecular species, the activation barrier potential is related to the structural solvation pressure, ps and shear, τs as (14)τs=Qy+psΩy-Eyφy * where Ey is the barrier height for the Eyring model, Qy is the process activation energy, Ωy is the pressure activation volume where pressure, ps is acting upon and φy * is the shear activation volume. The shear activation volume, φy * is interpreted as the size of the segment that moves during the shear stress process. This volume can be a molecule or a dislocation line. The pressure activation volume, Ωy is associated with the local increase in volume to permit the molecular motion to occur.

sec.title: Computation procedure
sec.p: The focus of this study is to address the physics underlying wet adhesion and elastoplastic behaviour of any given fractal based sample, which does not change according to the sample itself. Therefore, as a first approximation, the study uses the fractal parameters, D and G given in Kogut and Komvopoulos51 to accurately reconstruct a typically measured rough surface domain. The area of surface reconstructed is a representative area of a larger fairly smooth surface. In the reconstruction process, the random phase, φn in equation (3) is generated using a random number generator, which uniformly distributes the phase over the interval [0, 1).

Figure 4(a) shows the generated fractal rough surface. A reference plane, acting as an approaching smooth surface, is used to determine the total area, A′tot where asperities are truncated at a given location, z (Figure 4(b)). The method of using a flat smooth reference plane approaching a rough surface has been proven by Greenwood and Tripp52 in order to produce similar load and area of contact of two rough surfaces. The truncated asperities are assumed to adhere to the reference plane, leading to direct surface to surface interaction or dry contact. To compute the dry contact friction for a fractal rough geometry, Fadh (equation (2)) is expressed as (15)Fadh=∑A'=0 A'L [dFadh(A')×n(A') ] where A′ = π(a′)2 is the asperity truncated area while the truncated asperity size distribution function, n(A′) are expressed as (16)n(A')=D-1 2A'L (A'LA' )(D+1)/2 with A′L = A′tot.(3 − D)/(D − 1). The term dFadh is obtained using equations (5) to (12) for a given truncated contact radius, a′. The same can be done to compute the load-carrying capacity of the rough surface contact by repeating the steps above using equation (9), which describes a single asperity interaction. Figure 4.
Various contact regions – Dry and wet contact.

However, for a reference plane at z (e.g. 10 nm), there are some regions where asperity truncation do not occur. In these regions as shown in Figure 4(b), there is a gap between the reference plane and the surface topography. A thin surface film of lubricant species may be formed in such regions, whose contribution to friction is through viscous shear. These asperities are assumed to be in wet contact, undergoing either viscous shear (Fv) or boundary lubrication (Fs). If the gap between the surface feature and the reference plane is more than 10 nm, it is assumed that viscous shear occurs. Hence, friction as a result of lubricant shearing is computed using the viscous shear component in equation (1). When the gap is less than 10 nm, equation (18) applies. The load-carrying capacity, Ws and friction force, Fs as a result of boundary lubrication on a fractal geometry are computed assuming the gap to be distance r* (17)Ws=∫ps(r*)dxdy
(18)Fs=∫τs(r*)dxdy The terms ps and τs are computed using equations (13) and (14), respectively. The pair correlation function, g* in equation (13) is computed using the statistical mechanics approach proposed by Chong et al.41 It should be noted that different contributions to friction occur at the same locations within the contact. However, the overall contributions must be added in order to obtain the total friction. Therefore, using equation (1), the total friction force for a reference plane at location, z for a fractal rough surface can be computed. The results shown in the following section uses the simulation parameters as summarised in Table 1.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
For the purpose of simulation, hard spheres of σα = 1 nm diameter are used as the solvent molecules. These are supplemented by spherical chains of nominal diameter, σβ 0.5 nm as the solute molecules. A total packing fraction of ηtot * is assumed for a fluidic volume, constrained within nominally smooth solid boundaries. Therefore, for the fluid mixture, the packing fraction for the long chain and hard spherical molecules becomes ηhs *=(1-rw)ηtot *ηhc *=rwηtot * where rw is the concentration ratio of the hard chain molecules added to the solvent's spherical molecules. Figure 5 shows the normalised pressure and shear stress for the fluid mixture confined by smooth solid boundaries of various polymeric chains at different solute concentration ratios. The linear chain molecules investigated include a monomer (e.g methane, CH4), 4-mer (e.g. butane, C4H10) and a 16-mer (e.g. hexadecane, C16H34). For a 16-mer, it can be observed that for a packing fraction of ηtot *=0.2, there exists a minimum normalised shear with a high load-carrying capacity at a solute concentration of approximately 0.1 or 10%. Figure 5.
Normalised pressure and shear for a fluid mixture of different polymeric chains confined within solid barriers.

Assuming a fluid mixture with 10% of added linear chain molecules (16-mer), Figure 6 illustrates the different fractal geometries generated with the corresponding total friction. The viscous friction component, Fv assuming the relative velocity between the surfaces to be 0.2 m/s is included for sake of completeness of the analysis. It is observed that the friction for the considered geometry with the height scaling parameter, G = 1 × 10−13 m, which represents the roughest surface of all, is dominated by direct asperity interactions, except for growing levels of separation. With an increasing gap, there is reducing level of asperity truncation. This means decreased dry boundary interaction (adhesion). Therefore, there is a trend towards dominance of viscous friction with an increasing gap. When a coherent film of bulk lubricant is encountered, viscous friction would be the only contribution. This corresponds to hydrodynamic conditions, where friction is inversely proportional to the thickness of any coherent lubricant film. This condition is not reached in the current analysis because of the insufficient gap size. However, in transition towards hydrodynamic condition, reducing levels of asperity truncation leads to a form of mixed regime of lubrication where surface adsorbed low shear strength film accounts for the main contribution to friction. In this region of the characteristics, the friction of very thin adsorbed film remains almost independent of the gap size, owing to its thinness and low shear strength. Therefore, at larger separations (e.g. >20 nm but less than a coherent hydrodynamic film), there appears to be asymptotic-type friction behaviour. In reality, with the sliding condition, this region of characteristics would eventually merge into hydrodynamic lubricant behaviour (i.e. this is not an asymptotic characteristic). This is indicated by the arrow in the Figures, indicating eventual hydrodynamic condition. At the other extreme of friction characteristics (diminishing gap), a greater number of asperity interactions takes place, which results in increasing adhesion. As G is reduced, there is a lower asperity height range, leading to a higher influence of boundary lubrication. Another point to note is that with the reduction of asperity height range, the elastoplastic deformation of the fractal geometry is also reduced. This is because the asperities with larger heights and smaller radii of curvature for rougher surfaces tend to deform plastically, leading to increased friction. The predictions may be regarded as naturally axiomatic. Figure 6.
Total friction force for fractal surfaces with fractal dimension, D = 2.3 at various height scaling parameter, G values as in Kogut and Komvopoulos.51

Figure 7 shows the variation in the contact area with respect to the separation between the reference plane and the mean surface height for the investigated fractal geometries. The inset plot to the Figure illustrates the region where dry and lubricated contacts occur at 10 nm. For an apparent contact area, A of 1 μm2 at mean surface height of 10 nm, the truncated asperity contact area is approximately 0.15 μm2, leaving the remainder of the contact lubricated or wetted. Figure 7.
Contact area of a fractal geometry with fractal dimension, D = 2.3 at various height scaling parameter, G as in Kogut and Komvopoulos.51

Figure 8 shows the friction contribution due to boundary adhesion. A comparison of elastic and elastoplastic deformation analysis is included for the three different fractal surfaces investigated. It can be seen that elastoplastic deformation increases friction and at the same time reducing the load-carrying capacity. This finding is in line with experience of increased friction in scuffed and scarred conjunctions. Figure 8.
Load and friction force for a fractal surface with fractal dimension, D = 2.3 at various height scaling parameter, G values as in Kogut and Komvopoulos51 – elastoplastic dry adhesion contact only.

Figure 9 shows the contribution to friction made by the solvation effect only with different concentrations of solute molecules for a 16-mer (e.g. hexadecane). As the asperity height range reduces (a smoother surface), the solvation is observed to increase the load-carrying capacity of the contact at the expense of higher friction. Note that the solvation effect is enhanced at smoother bounding solid barriers.29 The analysis shows the underlying reason to be the increased ratio of contact surface area to the effective molecular size. Another point to note is that when the solute concentration is increased from 0.001 to 0.1, the friction remains almost the same, but the load-carrying capacity is only marginally improved. However, a further increase in the concentration of chain molecules to 0.5 reduces not only the friction, but also the load-carrying capacity, which is clearly not ideal. The reduction in load capacity at higher concentrations of solute chain molecules is expected as the fluid now lacks the load-carrying capacity of the solvent species, which is shown by Chong et al.40 Therefore, an optimum level of concentration of solute molecules of a certain type and function may be found to suit a lubricant composition, based upon the metrics of performance: friction and load-carrying capacity, at least at the scale of asperities. However, the complexity of the problem also becomes apparent in devices where a plethora of contact conditions exist at the microscale, for example in an internal combustion engine. In some cases a greater emphasis is put on lower friction (piston system), whilst for others load-carrying capacity is predominant (valve trains). Figure 9.
Load and friction force for a fractal surface with fractal dimension, D = 2.3 at various height scaling parameter, G values as in Kogut and Komvopoulos51 – solvation only.

The comparison of predicted load-carrying capacity and friction force using various assumptions including the typical Hertzian approach is given in Figure 10. It is shown that the Hertzian assumption without any adhesion (Adh), solvation (Solv) and elastoplasticity (Ep) under-estimates the contact friction. The inclusion of elastoplasticity of the conjunction increases friction because of higher rate of asperity ploughing. As a consequence, the load-carrying capacity of a plastically deformed rough surface is reduced (Figure 10(a)). Figure 10.
Contact load and friction force predicted for a fractal geometry (D = 2.3, G = 1 × 10−15 m) using various contact assumptions.

In Figure 11, predicted friction between a purely dry adhered contact (no solvation) and a lubricated contact (with solvation) shows an insignificant difference. However, the introduction of a boundary film within the conjunction not only reduces the ‘stickiness’ of the surface, but it also increases the load-carrying capacity of the contact (Figure 11(a)). At 3.75 nm mean surface height of a 1 μm × 1 μm apparent contact area, the increased load-carrying capacity is approximately 1%. As an example, Pattona and Zabinski53 showed that for a typical MEMS RF switch, the apparent contact area ranges from 3 to 1000 μm2. Hence, in practice, the predicted increase in load-carrying capacity (Figure 11(a)) would be quite significant. Figure 11.
Contact load and friction force for a fractal geometry (D = 2.3, G = 1 × 10−15 m) considering dry adhesion and elastoplasticity.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Friction of rough sliding surfaces plays an important role in the dynamics performance of many machines. Real rough surfaces comprise many asperities which are often randomly distributed. Traditional boundary friction models, developed for microscale interactions, do not apply to randomly distributed topology and often lack combined adhesion and elastoplastic ploughing friction as well as representing any thin adsorbed film through the non-Newtonian Eyring shear stress. The current contribution presents a friction model at fractal level, combining the effects of asperity adhesion, elastoplastic deformation and a thin adsorbed boundary active molecular layer. It is shown that if boundary adsorbed fluid films are ignored, contact friction is over-estimated and the load capacity of the contact is under-estimated. The current model forms the basis for the development of a generic multi-species lubricant-random roughness surface methodology.

ack.p: The authors acknowledge the technical support from partners and sponsorship provided by the EPSRC through the ENCYCLOPAEDIC program grant.

sec.p: This research is funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Council (EPSRC).

sec.title: Appendix 2
sec.p: The set of expressions below are a combination of finite element analysis and analytical approximations. The critical interference, δc refers to the initial point of yielding. Jackson and Green23 derived the expression for δc using the von Mises criterion. The Poisson's ratio used in the model is for the material which has the lower yield strength of the two contacting surfaces. Using the critical interference, the critical load, Pc can be computed. These critical values analytically predict the onset of yield. The model can also support the fully plastic deformation of the contact. Sy in the model is the von Mises yield criterion while HG is the limiting average pressure of the material. P¯1= {a¯3⇒ if δ*<δtPepπΔγR⇒ if δ*≥δt δ¯1= {a¯2⇒ if δ*<δtδep (16E*29π2Δγ2R )1 3⇒ if δ*≥δt P¯=P3πΔγRa¯=a (4E*9πΔγR2 )1 3δ¯=δ (16E*29π2Δγ2R )1 3}
